ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would summarize this course as a great class to take. Carla helped me learn so much about Early Childhood Education, and I am excited to take more courses with her, and Nancy Close next semester and next year.

This is definitely a class that you have to be intentional about taking because it requires a lot of "extra" time--i.e for commuting and for observations. To get the most of the class, make sure you have time to enjoy it. The journals are very straight-forward, mostly observations and then your reflections. Start on the final paper early!
Take it if you get a spot.

Thorough class that explores many aspects of early childhood. The class is a commitment because of weekly observations. Generally an excellent class with a thoughtful professor and great environment to have class in.

An interdisciplinary seminar with observations of practice and discussions of theory, very engaging and one of the best classes at Yale. I would highly recommend to anyone interested in kids, schools or education in general.
Absolutely take CHLD 127 if you get the chance. The course is a surprising amount of work but grading is pretty lenient and the material is interesting so it never feels burdensome.
